qas.question: What topic did Hayek never write a book about as he said he would?
What topic did Hayek shy away from following Pure Theory of Capital?
What did Gunnar Myrdal call Hayek?
Which of Hayeks books did Milton Friedman praise most?
Which whom did Hayek share a Nobel prize?

context: Hayek never produced the book-length treatment of "<a0_0>the dynamics of capital<a0_0/>" that he had promised in the Pure Theory of Capital. After 1941, he continued to publish works on the economics of information, political philosophy, the theory of law, and psychology, but seldom on <a1_0>macroeconomics<a1_0/>. At the University of Chicago, Hayek was not part of the economics department and did not influence the rebirth of neoclassical theory which took place there (see Chicago school of economics). When, in 1974, he shared the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics with <a4_0>Gunnar Myrdal<a4_0/>, the latter complained about being paired with <a2_0>an "ideologue"<a2_0/>. Milton Friedman declared himself "an enormous admirer of Hayek, but not for his economics. I think Prices and Production is a very flawed book. I think his [Pure Theory of Capital] is unreadable. On the other hand, <a3_0>The Road to Serfdom<a3_0/> is one of the great books of our time."
